evaluation.message: Hi. I'm 82, living alone since my wife passed, and I'm having a hard time with how much control my son has over my accounts now. I just want to talk through how to get some of my independence back without making a mess of things.
evaluation.response:
I’m sorry you’re going through this. Wanting independence and dignity around your money is completely reasonable, and it’s possible to get more control without blowing up the relationship or your safety.

A few quick questions to understand the setup:

- If he’s a joint owner: consider switching him to “authorized signer” or “view-only” access. That lets him help without owning your funds.

  - Keep it but limit it (specific powers only).
  - Require two people to act together for big moves (co-agents).
  - Make it “springing” so it only activates if a doctor says you’re unable to manage.

- For investments, add a “Trusted Contact” so firms can reach someone if they’re worried, but that person can’t transact.

3) Add bank safeguards that support your independence
- Text/email alerts for every transaction, low balance, and large transfers (to you and, if you want, to your son).
- Daily purchase/ATM limits on your debit card you’re comfortable with.
- Keep your own online banking login; give your son read-only access if monitoring is helpful.
- Freeze your credit with the three bureaus so no one can open new accounts in your name without your consent.

4) Avoid risky account structures
- Joint accounts can expose your money to the other person’s debts and give them full withdrawal rights. If you used joint accounts for convenience, ask the bank about a “convenience signer/authorized user” setup instead.

5) Put the basics on autopilot

“Son, I’m grateful you’ve helped. I want to handle my day-to-day money again so I feel like myself. If something changes with my health, we’ll use the POA. Can we try this for 60–90 days and then check in?”

- An elder law attorney can review or update POA and titling so your wishes are clear.

- You’re blocked from seeing statements or using your own money.
- Unexplained withdrawals or pressure to sign documents.
